awd_titl_txt: Travel: New Statistical Physics of Living Matter: non-equilibrium states under adaptive control
awd_abstract_narration:
This travel award supports the participation of junior and senior US researchers in the program “New statistical physics in living matter: non equilibrium states under adaptive control” that takes place July-December 2023 at the Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences of the University of Cambridge, UK. The program will initiate discussions among a wide range of researchers about the fundamental physics and mathematical modeling of biological systems, with a focus on active, far-from-equilibrium properties and the consequences of these for adaptive control. The interdisciplinary nature of the research can impact a variety of fields from materials science and engineering, physics, applied mathematics, biology to medicine. About one third of the more than 100 participants will be from US institutions, including 10-15 junior researchers. The program includes four week-long workshops, consisting of typically 24 invited and 15-20 contributed talks that emphasize representation of younger scientists and underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project funded the participation of US-based researchers in a six-month workshop at the Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences at the University of Cambridge in the UK. The workshop brought together researchers from around the world specializing in Physics and Mathematics approaches and applications to understanding biological systems. Participants working in Physics, Mathematics, Engineering, and Biology came together to discuss recent research, present recent findings, and initiate new collaborations in an exciting and growing field at the interface between Biology and the Physical Sciences. As part of this workshop, there were also four focused meetings bringing in additional speakers to present cutting-edge research in this area, ranging from insights gleaned from living systems for the design of novel active materials to understanding viral assembly and possible new physics-based approaches to address the growing challenge of anti-bacterial resistance. 

Funding from this grant helped make possible the participation of researchers from US institutions, who made up one-third of the over 100 participants from all countries. 

This workshop was one of the first fully in-person workshops of its kind since Covid and provided a welcome boost and reinvigoration to research efforts and new collaborations for researchers, as well as career advancement of junior researchers in the field. Immediate achievements include new fundamental results on non-equilibrium aspects of living systems and active matter. Plans are also in place for follow-up activities in the form of short workshops at international venues in Europe, Asia, Africa, and the US to further strengthen this research community.
